description.hltext_display: . العثمان: أكبر مبلغ يُخصص لجامعة الملك سعود منذ تأسيسها قبل 54 عاما
description.content:
رفع مدير جامعة الملك سعود معالي الدكتور عبدالله بن عبدالرحمن العثمان الشكر والتقدير باسمه وباسم منسوبي ومنسوبات الجامعة لخادم الحرمين الشريفين الملك عبد الله بن عبد العزيز آل سعود ولنائبه الأمير سلطان بن عبد العزيز ولي العهد وللنائب الثاني الأمير نايف بن عبد العزيز حفظهم الله على ما خُصص للجامعة من الميزانية العامة للدولة هذا العام 1432/1433.
وقال معاليه في تصريح صحفي اليوم انه على الرغم من الأزمات الاقتصادية التي هزت العالم ظلت بلادنا بفضل الله ثم بحكمة القيادة الحكيمة بمأمن من ذلك فلم تتأثر بشيء بل وتواصلت فيها جهود البناء والإصلاح وإطلاق المشروعات الكبيرة والتوسع فيها عاماً بعد عام .
وأضاف قائلا تتجلى في كل ميزانية تعلنها الدولة مدى عناية خادم الحرمين الشريفين الملك عبدالله بن عبد العزيز يحفظه الله ببناء الدولة والإنسان حيث تركَّزت ميزانية هذا العام التي تُعد الأضخم في تاريخ المملكة على البعد الإنساني والبعد التنموي عبر التوسع الكمي والنوعي في أهم الخدمات التي يحتاجها المواطن كالتعليم والرعاية الصحية اللذان يُعدان محورين في سياسة الإصلاح التي انتهجتها حكومة البلاد منذ سنوات إضافة إلى تركيز الميزانية على إطلاق المشروعات التي تعزز استمرار النمو والتنمية وتتيح المزيد من الفرص الوظيفية للمواطنين .
ودلل معاليه على ذلك بتخصيص 256 ملياراً لمشروعات جديدة وتوسعات في مشروعات سابقة لتحقيق رفاه المواطن وتوفير حياة كريمة له في بيئة مثالية تتوفر فيها كافة الخدمات.
وأوضح الدكتور عبدالله العثمان إلى أن المتأمل في سجل الأرقام الواردة في إعلان الميزانية يبرز البعد المعرفي ممثلاً في قطاع التعليم بوصفه الأهم بين كافة القطاعات بدليل حجم المخصص له البالغ 137,600,000 ويمثل 24% من مجموع الميزانية وهي النسبة الأكبر بين كل القطاعات،مبينا أن هذه العناية تجسد وعي القيادة برسالة التعليم، وأنه الخيار الوحيد للنهضة بالوطن والمواطن لكون الاستثمار في الإنسان هو أكثر أشكال الاستثمار أهمية وربحية ويعد النجاح في بناء العقل البشري شرطاً لنجاح أي مشروع حضاري أو تنموي.
وزاد بقوله ورد ضمن المشروعات المعتمدة لهذا القطاع تهيئة المحاضن النموذجية لبناء العقل البشري بإنشاء آلاف المدارس الجديدة في قطاع التعليم العام وتزويدها بالأجهزة والمعامل اللازمة لنضج العملية التعليمية وفي قطاع التعليم العالي سيتواصل استكمال إنشاء المدن الجامعية ومستشفياتها ومساكن أعضاء هيئاتها التدريسية في عدد من المناطق كما سيستمر نشاط برنامج خادم الحرمين الشريفين للابتعاث الخارجي.
وأردف معالي مدير جامعة الملك سعود قائلا انه بالنظر إلى حجم المبالغ المخصصة للجامعات نجد أن جامعة الملك سعود قد حظيت بالميزانية الأكبر حيث خُصص لها مبلغ 7,843,363,000 وهو أكبر مبلغ يُخصص للجامعة منذ تأسيسها قبل أكثر من 54 عاماً مؤكدا أن ما خُصص للجامعة هو أمانة ومسؤولية تلزم ترجمتها بدقة إلى واقع مشاهد ينهض بالإنسان ويتحول بالمجتمع إلى مجتمع معرفي يحتضن ثقافة المعرفة ويؤمن بدورها في تأسيس السمات الجديدة للوطن الحديث.
وانتهى الدكتور عبدالله العثمان الى القول أن جامعة الملك سعود تقرأ الرسالتين بوضوح وتتعهد بالالتزام في مواصلة استراتيجياتها التطويرية الهادفة إلى أن تكون جامعة رائدة على مستوى العالم قادرة على صناعة تحولات في حركة التعليم
تبرزه في صورة جديدة وتجعله مؤثراً في سياقات النهضة بالوطن.
ودعا المولى عز وجل أن يحفظ خادم الحرمين الشريفين وأن يمد في عمره وأن يمتعه بالصحة والعافية وأن يكتب الحفظ والرعاية لولي عهده الأمين ولنائبه الثاني وأن يجعلهما في عافية وسلامة دائمة.

description.hltext_display: After Yesterday's Rally of 7.64%, Rare Element Resources Shares Could Potentially Pullback (REE)
description.content:
Rare Element Resources (NYSE:REE) traded in a range yesterday that spanned from a low of $9.60 to a high of $10.64. Yesterday, the shares gained 7.64%, which took the trading range above the 3-day high of $10.14 on volume of 6.9 million shares. Often times after large one-day gains, short term traders will seek to take profits and, as such, investors should be cautious.
Shares of Rare Element Resources are currently trading above their 50-day moving average (MA) of $10.14 and above their 200-day MA of $5.24. Look for the MA to provide support for a short-term pullback in the shares.
SmarTrend currently has shares of Rare Element Resources in an Uptrend and issued the Uptrend alert on July 06, 2010 at $2.02. The stock has risen 373.9% since the Uptrend alert was issued.
SmarTrend expects the share price to pullback toward the $10.14 support level. Afterwards, we expect it to move upward with its peers in the SmarTrend Industrial Metals & Minerals industry.
Keywords: rare element resources trading range stock news

description.hltext_display: Mexicans face exile by fear
description.content:
I have never before thought of myself as an exile. All my life I have traveled between Mexico, where I was born, and Los Angeles, my home since I was 6. What do I, whose parents freely chose to leave their country for the United States so many years ago, have in common with Vietnamese, Cubans, Iranians and Iraqis who were forced to flee their homelands, never to return?
Fear.
The headlines tell the story: "Mexico Under Siege," "Deadly Drug Violence Claims Hundreds of Lives," "U.S. Warns of Danger in Mexico as Violence Increases." Or the one about the 14-year-old who matter-of-factly told authorities he had killed people by chopping off their heads and then added, as if exonerating himself, that at least he "never went and hung the bodies from bridges or anything like that."
That story is particularly chilling to me because many of those bodies were hung from bridges in Cuernavaca, the city where my mother's family lives, where I spent summers visiting from the United States. Friends there tell stories of shielding their children's eyes from the dangling corpses that seem to be falling from the sky.
In Cuernavaca, and in Mexico City, our friends do not leave their homes at night. Conversations in restaurants are whispered -- no one wants to be overheard saying so-and-so was kidnapped or that so-and-so is a narco. You never know who is sitting next to you. Many people we know have been kidnapped. The 2007 death of Silvia Vargas, a highly publicized kidnapping, hit close to home. Her dad was once my summer swim coach.
That 14-year-old killer is part of a new generation in Mexico that is being called los ni-nis, the "neither-nors," lost boys and young men who proclaim they neither study nor work. They have found plenty to do, however, acting as the cartels' killers, mules and torturers. Usually, the reports say, they are so doped up, they don't even recognize or feel the carnage they are inflicting.
I know that, as with most countries, Mexico has always had a dark and wild side. My own mother and aunt were kidnapped by a powerful cacique in the 1960s. He thought my 14-year-old aunt, with her green eyes, white skin and black hair, was so beautiful he had to have her.
Fortunately, my nervy and intelligent mother was with her, and she was able to figure out an escape: opening the door of the moving car, grabbing her little sister's hand and running against traffic down Mexico City's largest boulevard.
For several months after the kidnapping, my aunt was escorted to school every day by a friend who was a general in the army. The issue was resolved quietly by my grandfather, a military doctor, when he met privately with the cacique. Nobody knows what was said, but the dirty old man never bothered my aunt or mother again.
In the 1980s and '90s, there were always stories of crimes. During the summers I spent with my cousins in Mexico, we were trained to give a cop his bribe and never allow them to take us in. Somehow, the crime stories always had a twist of kindness or mercy to them that made them almost comical. In his early 80s, my stepgrandfather was mugged every week after depositing his money in the bank at the same time on Fridays. But the muggers were always polite and apologized for having to take his money. A friend who was carjacked was given bus fare.
There is nothing funny in the stories being told today. There is only fear and lament. And yet, life goes on. My cousins, aunts and uncles will all spend Christmas in Acapulco. They will dance, eat, swim in the sea. I hear the sadness in my grandmother's voice when I tell her we won't be visiting this year. I feel my voice catching as I think about her, 90 years old, sitting in her living room holding the telephone. I remember how beautiful Christmastime is in Mexico, everything decorated in the crimson hues of the season.
I can see the poinsettias, noche buenas, blooming in the languid gardens in Cuernavaca, a place the Aztecs called the City of Eternal Spring. The Mexico I like to remember is about love and warmth and family.
I know I am giving in to the media frenzy that sensationalizes the crimes and only covers the horrors in Mexico. But now I have children of my own, and having children makes one a coward.
If my family were to make the trip, most likely, the worst wouldn't happen. After all, the majority of the violence is occurring between drug dealers and their henchmen. Crime rates in general are much worse in Brazil and Venezuela, for instance.
It is an ugly, ugly time in Mexico. So now I, too, have joined the ranks of so many immigrants, exiled in fear, who dare not go back. To be honest, we cannot -- because the place and the time we seek no longer exists.
• Lorenza Munoz is a former Los Angeles Times staff writer. She wrote this for the Los Angeles Times.

event_or_fact.property: this for the Los Angeles Times

description.hltext_display: Special children’s Christmas Eve program: You’re invited
description.content:
mmunity is invited to share in a special interactive children’s Christmas program at the First Presbyterian Church on Christmas Eve. The program will begin at 5 p.m. and last about 30 minutes.
This service is designed specifically with young children in mind. Costumes will be available for any children who want to participate.
A candlelight communion service will begin at 7 p.m.
The First Presbyterian Church is located at 1101 Millington St.

description.hltext_display: Asset lender Encino – Some points to get in touch with a good one
description.content:
Edit Article | Posted: Dec 22, 2010 |Comments: 0 |
Share
Are you looking out for a good asset lender Encino to get the best loan? Well if this is the case then you can hunt for them on the web. There are many options available to you for the purpose of getting in touch with the best asset lender of Encino. But before you approach any asset lender you will first have to make sure that he is just perfect for you. You will have to make sure that he passes all the required qualification. There are certain important qualifications that an asset lender should have. If at all the asset lender you have approached follows all the below mentioned features then you can surely get in touch with them and take a good loan amount for your emergency cash requirement.
The first and the most important feature of the asset lender Encino is that it should be a company that has a good amount of experience in the field of pawning or asset lending. This is a profession where people needs high level of reliability and that you can get only when you have a good amount experience in the field of asset lending. So make sure that a well experienced company should be looked for that can offer you good loan amount and that too with high level of reliability.
In addition to this you will have to make sure that the asset lender Encino offers you asset loan for all the types of asset. There are many types of assets that are preferred in order to get asset loan. Assets like jewelry, land, property, vehicle, watches, guitars, electronics, etc are generally preferred by the lenders. So make sure that you look for a lender that offers you loan for all the types of assets and it should not be specific to a particular asset.
After this you will have to look out for an asset lender that is very easy to reach. Make sure that you specify your search for such lenders that are in and around your county. It will be feasible for you to look for a lender that is easy to reach and not a lender that stays in different county overall. If at all there is a good lender but it is very far from you then it makes no point approaching such people. So make sure that you look out for a provider who is in or around your county.

description.hltext_display: علماء سعوديون يكتشفون طريقة جديدة لتوصيل مسكن الألم للجروح الفموية عبر فيلم لآصق
description.content:
توصل علماء سعوديون إلى اكتشاف طبي عالمي جديد بقيادة الدكتور خالد بن عبدالله الحزيمي الباحث الرئيس, المشرف على كرسي أبحاث المهندس عبدالله بقشان للعوامل المحفزة وبناء العظام بجامعة الملك سعود, الأستاذ المساعد،قسم وقاية الأسنان، بكلية طب الأسنان جامعة الملك سعود والأستاذ الدكتور إبراهيم السراء أحد الخبراء العالميين في هذا المجال,كلية الصيدلة,جامعة الملك سعود, والدكتور زياد سلامة الباحث المتخصص بكرسي المهندس بقشان للعوامل المحفزة وبناء العظام بالتوصل إلى اكتشاف طبي جديد مهم. وكانت احد نتائج هذه الأبحاث استحداث ولأول مرة طريقة جديدة لتوصيل مسكن الألم للجروح الفموية عبر فيلم لاصق. تم قبول هذه الورقة العلمية في الأكاديمية الأمريكية لعلوم اللثة وزراعة الأسنان في 18 نوفمبر, ونظر لأنها طريقة جديدة ومهمة قامت بنشرها في 7 ديسمبر من هذا العام.
وقام الموقع الطبي الأمريكي الشهير بتصنيف هذا البحث كمرجعية علمية عالمية وأعطي الترتيب السادس انقر هنا .
الجدير بالذكر أن الموقع تأسس 1990 في واشنطن بالولايات المتحدة الأمريكية ويعنى بالأبحاث المهمة التي لها تطبيقات سريريه ويكون لها مستقبليا سوق كبيرة اقتصاديا.وأبان الدكتور الحزيمي أن هذا يدل على مستوى البحث العلمي بالجامعة وخاصة كراسي البحث العلمي وكرسي المهندس بقشان الذي يعد الوحيد في طب الأسنان بالمملكة العربية السعودية. ,انجازات كرسي المهندس بقشان أصبحت ظاهرة محليا وإقليميا وعالميا.
وذكر الأستاذ الدكتور إبراهيم السراء والذي يعد من العلماء المتخصصين في هذا المجال أن هذا البحث أستغرق ما يقارب الأربع سنوات عملا وأن فوائده كبيرة خاصة للمرضى الذين لا يستطيعون أخذ مسكنات الألم لأسباب طبية كالقرحة, أو قد تسبب هذه الأدوية تفاعلا مع الأدوية الأخرى التي يأخذها المريض لعلاج أمراض أخرى.وأنه مع هذا الاكتشاف سيتم تفادي هذه المضاعفات.الجدير بالذكر أن هذا الاكتشاف الطبي العالمي سيكون له تطبيقات سريريه للمرضى وهذا من الانجازات البحثية التي يقدمها كرسي المهندس بقشان بالإضافة إلى المنجزات الأخرى ويأتي هذا من الدعم المباشر للأبحاث الطبية من أدارة الجامعة ممثلة في معالي مدير الجامعة الدكتور عبدالله العثمان.

description.hltext_display: AFC South: Colts' ground game, defense answer the call
description.content: (Sports Network) - Anyone who has watched Peyton Manning and the Indianapolis Colts over the past few seasons hasn't seen the club challenged very often. However, 2010 hasn't been one of domination by the club and the Colts went into Sunday's home game against the Jaguars needing a win to prevent Jacksonville from clinching the AFC South. That's just what they got; a 34-24 victory that saw Indianapolis use its ground game to control things while stopping the Jags' red-hot run attack. Turns out that was head coach Jim Caldwell's plan all along. "Those were our two challenges. Coach Caldwell made that challenge to us [last] Monday," said Manning. "He challenged both the interior fronts on both sides of the ball, for us to run the ball and for our defense to stop the run. Both answered the bell. Both answered the challenge." Running back Donald Brown ripped off a career-high 129 yards and scored a touchdown, while the Colts held the Jaguars' Maurice Jones-Drew to just 46 yards on 15 carries. Jones-Drew had gone over 100 yards in six straight games. And with that the Colts are back in control of the AFC South. Two victories over the season's final two weeks -- at Oakland this Sunday before a home finale on Jan. 2 versus Tennessee -- and Indianapolis will have its ninth straight postseason berth and seventh division title in eight seasons. The 8-6 Colts have now won two straight since a three-game slide threatened to derail their season. "This is one win. It is all about Oakland this week," said Manning. "You can take a step back and you feel like these last two wins don't mean as much. Hopefully we can feed off of a little momentum of two wins in a row and play well on the road. But we know we will have our hands full going out there. At Oakland is a tough place to play against a good football team." The rest of the NFL is so used to seeing Manning make plays with his arm, that Brown and the ground game probably snuck up on the Jaguars. Manning said the success of the running backs also helped the play action, which the Colts ran during the second quarter on Austin Collie's second touchdown reception of the game. Collie, though would exit the game early with his second concussion of the season. The wideout had missed three straight and four of the last five games with a concussion suffered versus the Philadelphia Eagles on Nov. 7. Caldwell didn't have an update on Collie after the game, other than to confirm the concussion and say the receiver was doing fine, but its tough to imagine him suiting up again this season. TITANS: The Tennessee Titans were able to give their home fans one more victory in 2010 and keep their slim playoff hopes alive in the process. The Titans snapped a six-game skid with a 31-17 win over the Houston Texans in their final home game of the season. Tennessee ends the year with road games against Kansas City and Indianapolis and needs to win both games, plus get some losses from the Colts and Jaguars, to make the postseason. "We're aware of those things. We understand what our situation is, who needs to do what," quarterback Kerry Collins said. "Is it a long shot? Yeah, it is but that's not going to change our MO. Want to come out, keep playing, crazier things have happened but we've got to take care of our business and we did that today." The 6-8 Titans picked up their first victory since Oct. 24 and did so without tight end Bo Scaife in the lineup. The six-year veteran was a healthy inactive, with second-year tight end Jared Cook, 23, getting the start. Cook ended with three catches for 42 yards, while Scaife had caught two touchdown passes last Thursday against the Colts to give him a career-high four on the season. "It was different for us. We're use to having Bo out there. [Head coach] Jeff [Fisher] made that decision and went along with it," Collins said. Fisher had mentioned last week that the Titans could start giving some different players a chance in the lineup. Fisher said after Sunday's game that the Titans needed to dress extra defensive linemen due to injuries, leaving Scaife and safety Vincent Fuller as the odd-men out. However, it is worth nothing that Scaife told The Tennessean last Wednesday that he thought the locker room might be divided due to the issues between Fisher and injured quarterback Vince Young, who was on the sidelines for part of the second half on Sunday. Young is on injured reserve due to a thumb injury. Despite those issues, the Titans were still able to enjoy Sunday's win, one that the team desperately needed. It came thanks to a pair of touchdown passes by Collins and 130 yards rushing and a score from running back Chris Johnson. "It feels real good," said Johnson. "It was kind of like we didn't know what it meant to really win no more, losing six straight and then really coming in here and getting a win. But we knew coming out of halftime what kind of team Houston is, they are a second half team and they put up a lot of points. So we just had to keep our feet on the gas." JAGUARS: Jacksonville head coach Jack Del Rio came into the season on the hot seat and there is no guarantee that just missing out on the playoffs will save his job. The Jaguars visited the Colts on Sunday needing a win to clinch their first division title since 1999. Instead, they dropped a 34-24 game and lost control of their own destiny. Now tied for first place in the AFC South with 8-6 Indianapolis, it is now the Colts who can claim the division with victories in their final two games regardless of what the Jags do this Sunday at home versus Washington and on Jan. 2 in Houston. "It's a bad feeling in my stomach," quarterback David Garrard said of his team losing control of its own fate. "But I know that we still have two games left. We need to go out and get two wins to give ourselves a chance. You never know what happens." Garrard set a club record by reaching 22 touchdown passes this season during the Colts game, but Jacksonville's excellent run attack was limited to just 67 yards. Star running back Maurice Jones-Drew was held to just 46 yards on the ground after going over 100 yards in each of his previous six games. "They did a good job of stopping our run," said tight end Marcedes Lewis. "Not too many times that will happen." Though they need help, these next two games will test Del Rio. If he hopes to be on the sidelines for the Jaguars for a ninth straight season in 2011, he has to find a way to get his club back into the postseason for the first time since 2007. Del Rio's job now is to make sure his team puts this tough loss behind them before Sunday's big game versus the Redskins. "Go forward; get ready to play the next one," he said he told his players after Sunday's game. "People want to assume things about our situation. We get two more opportunities to play as a football team. We need to go out and take care of business. Obviously we need help, but it's certainly not impossible that we'll get some." TEXANS: So what is actually bothering Houston Texans running back Arian Foster? Foster, the NFL's leading rusher with 1,345 yards this season, was limited to a season low 15 yards on 11 carries in Sunday's 31-17 loss in Tennessee that dropped Houston to 5-9 on the season. Foster didn't finish the game due to injury, but it is unclear what is actually ailing him. Head coach Gary Kubiak said after the game that Foster's ankle was bothering him. "He missed one day of practice last week. It's a little sore, but he got his ankle in the game." However, Foster said after the game that he had a muscle spasm on the glut, but that he could have played. Few can blame Kubiak for leaving his stud back on the sidelines given the deficit. So is it Foster's ankle, glut or both? We may never know the truth, though Kubiak stuck by his story on Monday saying again it was an ankle issue. What is no longer an issue is the on-field scrum between teammates Antonio Smith and Brian Cushing. Smith became angry after he felt a Titans player tried to cut-block him and he confronted the culprit. Cushing went after his teammate and eventually lost his helmet, leading to a penalty. "What happened is [Cushing] came to me and I can't remember what he said, but he grabbed me and head-butted me," said Smith. "It was in the heat of the moment type thing. I grabbed his facemask to pull him close to me so we can get eye to eye to say what I had to say, and as we are doing that teammates come in between and the helmet comes off and it looks like a big ordeal." Cushing said on Monday that the two patched things up right after the play. Houston's setback over the weekend dropped the club to 5-9, meaning the club will finish with a record below .500 for the first time since a 6-10 campaign in 2006. That is without a disappointment for a club that came into the season hoping to make the playoffs for the first time since joining the league in 2002. "I am extremely disappointed about how the season went," said quarterback Matt Schaub. "We had high hopes, and expectations were high. We still have expectations for this team and organization. We just need to find a way to play better football for 60 minutes for 16 weeks." Houston will hope to snap a three-game slide and avoid its eighth loss in nine games this Sunday at Denver.

description.hltext_display: 冷泉荘で公開講座「ハコザキボイス」
Corea del Sur lanza una nueva ola de maniobras militares
description.content:
SEÚL (AFP) - Corea del Sur anunció este miércoles una nueva ola de maniobras militares, tres días después de haber realizado ejercicios en una isla bombardeada por Pyongyang, lo que había disparado la tensión en la península coreana.
El ejército anunció que iba a realizar el jueves maniobras militares, terrestres y aéreas, con disparos reales, cerca de la frontera con Corea del Norte.
Estas maniobras se realizarán en Pocheon, a 20 kilómetros al sur de la frontera entre las dos Coreas, indicó un portavoz del ejército, que precisó que los ejercicios serán importantes. En varias ocasiones se han realizado maniobras similares en Pocheon, agregó.
Participarán en estos ejercicios 800 soldados, así como helicópteros, seis aviones de combate, tanques, misiles antitanque y lanzacohetes múltiples.
El ejército también anunció que este miércoles comenzaron unas maniobras navales que durarán cuatro días y que se desarrollan frente a la costa Este de la península coreana, en el Mar de Japón. Estos ejercicios se realizarán a casi un centenar de kilómetros de la frontera con Corea del Norte y en los mismos participarán seis buques de guerra y helicópteros.
El objetivo de las maniobras es entrenarse para responder en caso de intrusión de submarinos o de buques de patrulla de Corea del Norte en aguas surcoreanas, indicó el ejército. Los ejercicios "demostrarán la solidez de nuestra preparación militar", dijo el comandante del Primer Batallón Armado, Choo Eun-Sik, a la agencia surcoreana Yonhap. "Vamos a lanzar severas represalia si el Norte se aventura a otro acto de provocación como el bombardeo de Yeonpyeong", añadió.
El lunes, Seúl realizó breves ejercicios militares con fuego real en la isla de Yeonpyeong, a pesar de las amenazas de graves represalias lanzadas por Pyongyang. Corea del Norte finalmente decidió no responder.
El pasado 23 de noviembre, Corea del Norte bombardeó Yeonpyeong, en el primer ataque de una zona de civiles desde el fin de la Guerra de Corea (1953), matando a cuatro surcoreanos y provocando una protesta internacional.

description.hltext_display: NFC North: Bears still have work to do
description.content: (Sports Network) - Now that the Chicago Bears are back in the playoffs and NFC North champions for the first time since reaching the Super Bowl in 2006, there's still a few hurdles to clear before making a deep postseason run. The Bears clinched a division title in impressive fashion by handing the division-rival Minnesota Vikings a 40-14 beating on a frigid Monday night at TCF Bank Stadium in Minnesota. They overcame not knowing where the game was going to be held earlier in the week after the roof collapsed at the Metrodome and brushed off Brett Favre's return from a shoulder injury to wax their division co-tenants. Rookie defensive end Corey Wootton introduced himself to Favre by knocking the future Hall of Famer out of the game with a concussion on his first career sack during the second quarter. Wootton's sack was one of four recorded by a defense that generated five takeaways, including interceptions by cornerback Charles Tillman, safety Chris Harris and defensive end Julius Peppers. Peppers, in his first year with Chicago, was appreciative of his teammates. "I see these guys every day," Peppers said postgame. "I see these guys work. I see what type of players we have on this team and I see the coaches. The coaches don't accept anything but our best. "Anytime you have that combination of things working together, good things have to happen. The football gods make sure good things happen to people who work hard and do things right." Peppers contributed five tackles and two tipped passes for the Bears, who still have games remaining against the Jets and Packers. Home-field advantage appears to be headed Atlanta's way since the Falcons are 12-2, but the Bears are the first team to clinch a division this season. Chicago has won six of its last seven games and improved to 6-1 as the visitor. The road record and five straight wins as the visitor should strike fear in Chicago's playoff opponent since it has proven winning as the guest is not a problem. Quarterback Jay Cutler continued his solid play last night with three touchdown passes to just one interception, and rebounded from an ugly showing in a 36-7 home loss to New England in Week 14. Last night Cutler threw for just 194 yards, but has eight TD passes in his last four games. At this time of year the Bears can't afford sloppy performances, especially from their quarterback, and need running back Matt Forte at his best. Forte's season has been inconsistent and he ran for 92 yards on 17 carries against the Vikings. He has only two 100-yard rushing games this season and will be relied on heavily come playoff time. Return man Devin Hester set Chicago up with great field position last night and even established the all-time NFL record for kick return touchdowns with the 14th kick return TD of his career. Hester is tied with Eric Metcalf with 10 punt returns for a score and broke the combined mark previously held by Brian Mitchell. Hester was thankful for the rest of his special teams partners after his big game. "I know the success is from those guys," an emotional Hester said. "I hate sitting here and taking all the glory. I wish those other 10 guys were up here and you were asking them questions because they deserve to be up here. I love them. All the glory goes to them." Chicago is hoping all the glory will eventually end up in the Windy City. VIKINGS: Here we go again. The never-ending saga, or soap opera, that is Brett Favre reared its head possibly for the last time in Monday night's brutal loss to rival Chicago. The grizzled veteran, who was originally ruled out earlier in the week, shook off a shoulder injury before getting re-acquainted with the ground. Favre was sacked by Bears rookie DE Corey Wootton early in the second quarter and never returned after suffering what appeared to be a concussion. Favre's tumultuous season that has been riddled by injuries and off-the-field news came to a thud after making a gutsy return. Wootton ended any chance of a miraculous Favre comeback by slamming the QB to the frozen ground after he had led the Vikings to a touchdown on the opening drive. "He gave them a boost," acknowledged Bears head coach Lovie Smith. "Whenever you have one of the all-time great players to play the game all of a sudden be ready to go, it has to give your team a boost. But our guys met the challenge." Minnesota's two-year run as NFC North champions ended weeks ago, but this season has left many to wonder what happened and if this team can move on successfully under interim head coach Leslie Frazier. Finding a quarterback to run the show will be the team's next challenge since Favre appears ready to ride off in the sunset and Tarvaris Jackson has failed several times to prove that he can play at this level. Joe Webb may not be the answer either after he threw for 129 yards and a pair of interceptions. Webb also ran for a score. While the passing attack never got off the icy ground at TCF Bank Stadium -- the home of the University of Minnesota -- running back Adrian Peterson was inactive with an ankle injury and rookie Toby Gerhart got the start, rushing for a career-best 77 yards on 16 carries. The numbers were pretty even, but the Bears had the advantage by forcing five takeaways, including three INTs, and having return man Devin Hester, who had a 64-yard punt return for a score. The Vikings are hoping Peterson will make a return this weekend in Philadelphia and spoil the Eagles' chances of capturing an NFC East title on their watch. Witnessing a team celebrate on back-to-back weeks is not on Minnesota's agenda. LIONS: The upstart Detroit Lions are on their longest winning streak -- two games -- since a three-game run midway through the 2007 campaign. Detroit possibly ruined the playoff chances for both Green Bay and Tampa Bay with consecutive wins, and squeezed out a 23-20 overtime triumph against the Buccaneers on the road this past Sunday. Dave Rayner's 28-yard field goal in overtime snapped the Lions' NFL-record 26-game road losing streak. Detroit's last road win came in Chicago, 16-7, on October 28, 2007. Maurice Morris ran for 109 yards and a score on 15 carries and reached the 100-yard mark in rushing for the first time since last Dec. 20 versus Arizona. Drew Stanton had another strong day under center, throwing for 252 yards with a touchdown pass to Nate Burleson. Calvin Johnson was his usual dominant self with 152 yards on 10 receptions, but didn't have to do it alone this time. "That's been the whole plan for what we want to do offensively: to be that multi-dimensional group," said head coach Jim Schwartz, who earned his first road win at the helm. "Where, if you decided to try and take one thing away we can make you pay with the other. "We've been derailed in that a little bit at times, but we've found a way -- particularly later in the season under some adverse circumstances." The Lions' hopes were derailed when franchise quarterback Matthew Stafford went down for the second time this season with a shoulder injury, and it would be foolish to rush him back with two games left on the schedule. Detroit already knows what he means to the offense and putting him at risk in Miami or back at home versus Minnesota is not the best idea. Stanton should handle the snaps for the rest of the campaign to showcase his talents for possibly a backup gig somewhere else. Don't forget Detroit backup QB Shaun Hill is also out due to injury. PACKERS: "So close, yet so far away." -- Hall and Oates. Those words couldn't ring more true for the Green Bay Packers, who had the NFL's top team -- the New England Patriots -- on the ropes for most of Sunday's 31-27 road loss. It was the third consecutive road setback for a Packers team that is out of the wild card picture with an 8-6 record. A 6-4 mark in conference play won't help either and the absence of Aaron Rodgers didn't seem to bother Green Bay, as backup Matt Flynn surprised everyone with 251 yards and three scores with an interception. Flynn, as predicted by yours truly, was supposed to fail miserably on the hallowed grounds of Gillette Stadium, but was sacked and stripped off the ball on the game's final play by Patriots linebacker Tully Banta-Cain. New England DT Vince Wilfork landed on the loose ball and possibly squashed the Packers' chances of a playoff berth as well. Flynn was also sacked five times. "I think for the people that don't know Matt Flynn, I think they got to look inside and see what type of person and what kind of player he is," said Packers head coach Mike McCarthy. "To have your first start in the NFL against Tom Brady at New England, the level that they are playing at right now, Sunday Night Football, it doesn't get much bigger than that." Packers defensive end Ryan Pickett said the team is ready for the New York Giants at home so it can get this loss out of the way. Pickett also stated how confident Green Bay was in leaving Foxborough with a win, but the loss will be a building block for the rest of the season and possibly the playoffs. After hosting the Giants, the Packers will entertain NFC North-champion Chicago at Lambeau Field. The conditions won't bother the Bears since they play at Soldier Field and beat the Vikings outdoors at the University of Minnesota. Green Bay has won three straight at home and hopes to have Rodgers back in the fold. Rodgers sustained his second concussion of the season in a loss at Detroit on Dec. 12 and his status for Sunday is unclear. "Well, I don't have all the information for Aaron," McCarthy said Monday. "Just as I stated last night after the game, I'll have an update for you Wednesday. We're still going through our medical process now with all of our players." Two more wins and the Packers will be 10-6 and in the driver's seat for a postseason berth thanks to several tiebreaker scenarios. They sport a 6-4 mark in conference play and are battling with New Orleans and the Giants for a wild card berth.

description.hltext_display: Ejemplo de honradez: joven que devolvió S/.100 mil perdidos fue ascendido en su trabajo
description.content:
A muchos les pareció que la recompensa que recibió por su honestidad fue ?por decir lo menos- ínfima, pero las cosas mejoraron para Kevin Arango Aroni, el joven de 18 años que devolvió los 100 mil soles que encontró al interior de un bolso tipo canguro en un baño de su centro de labores.
Kevin dejará su puesto de ascensorista temporal ?fue contratado solo por campaña navideña- por el de empleado del área de informática de Saga Falabella. Así se lo informaron los ejecutivos de la empresa que resaltaron la honradez del joven que aspira a estudiar ingeniería de sistemas.
"Le estoy muy agradecido a mis padres y muy agradecido a Dios también porque sin él no estaría acá", declaró Arango al noticiero "90 Segundos".
El "service" que lo colocó como ascensorista también reconoció su honestidad y le dio S/.200 , el doble de dinero que le obsequió el dueño de los 100 mil soles como recompensa.

description.hltext_display: お掃除で心ピカピカ “洗浄士”が園児にコツ伝授
NFC West: Even with loss, Rams stay in driver's seat
description.content: (Sports Network) - In a week in which all four NFC West residents added to their loss column, it may be the St. Louis Rams who came away the most disappointed. Had the Seattle Seahawks not been defeated by the Atlanta Falcons on Sunday, or had the San Francisco 49ers not suffered defeat at the hands of the San Diego Chargers last Thursday, things would be a lot more gloomy for the Rams after they dropped a 27-13 decision to the Kansas City Chiefs. But while St. Louis was unable to slightly pull ahead of its competition, it didn't lose any ground either. Still, the Rams know they can only give away so many chances before it comes back to bite them. They remain tied with Seattle for first place despite a 6-8 record, with 5-9 San Francisco looming as well. After failing to take advantage of other teams helping them out, St. Louis now gets to take matters into its own hands. The Rams will play host to the 49ers this Sunday with a chance to make it a two-horse race again in the NFC West. After that, St. Louis will visit Seattle on Jan. 2 in a game that could very well decide the division title. "What I just told the football team was, if I have this thing figured out correctly, basically for us our regular season is over," head coach Steve Spagnuolo said after Sunday's loss. "Now, it's playoff mode for us. We've got to win the next game, that's the one we're focused on to have anything to do going forward. That's kind of where we're at." Should the Rams miss out on their first playoff appearance since 2004, which will have to come by way of their first division title since '03, few will look at 2010 as a disappointment for a club that had posted just six victories total in its previous three seasons. That didn't make the loss any easier for running back Steven Jackson, who after Sunday's setback disagreed with his coach that the club is now entering an early playoff mentality. "We should have been in playoff mode today," said the veteran back. "We put ourselves in this spot to fight and I don't want to seem like -- we still have an opportunity but we now have allowed for another team to come into the race. But this team has accomplished a lot." Jackson's touchdown with 4:04 left on Sunday represented St. Louis' first points since coming through with field goals on its first two possessions. Though quarterback Sam Bradford became just the third rookie to throw for 3,000 yards in a season -- Atlanta's Matt Ryan and Peyton Manning of Indianapolis are the others, which represents some pretty good company -- he was intercepted twice and sacked three times in the loss. St. Louis needs to help out its freshman signal-caller, as Bradford has thrown five picks and been sacked eight times over his last three games without a touchdown throw. 49ERS: With nine days between games, San Francisco 49ers head coach Mike Singletary has plenty of time to decide which quarterback he is going to start for this weekend's season-saving divisional game. San Francisco's quarterback situation has been a week-to-week thing ever since Troy Smith took over for an injured Alex Smith on Oct. 31. The former went on to start five straight games, even when Alex Smith's shoulder injury healed, but Singletary went back to his season-opening signal-caller on Dec. 12 versus Seattle. Alex Smith made a solid return, throwing three touchdown passes in a big 40-21 victory. However, the top pick of the 2005 draft struggled last Thursday versus the Chargers, completing 19-of-29 pass attempts for 165 yards without a touchdown throw. Smith was also intercepted once and sacked six times. Singletary doesn't think his offense will be impacted by another quarterback switch since both QBs have gotten plenty of playing time this season. "Yeah, I think that's what it boils down to. The guy that I think is going to give us that best chance to win," Singletary said last Friday. Last week's loss took control of its destiny away from 5-9 San Francisco, which remains one-game back of the NFC West co-leading Seattle and St. Louis. The Niners now need to win out -- this Sunday at St. Louis and then at home versus Arizona on Jan. 2 -- and get one loss from the Seahawks over the next two weeks to claim their first division title and playoff appearance since 2002. One has to wonder if Troy Smith has the advantage to start this weekend because of his performance in a Nov. 14, 23-20 overtime victory at home over the Rams. Smith threw for a career-high 356 yards in that game, including a 16-yard go-ahead touchdown pass to wide receiver Michael Crabtree with just 2:10 left in regulation before the Rams tied the game on a field goal as time expired. Singletary might not put much weight on that contest. "I just think that right now as we look at the film and look at the things that we want to do, I think when I look at the Rams when we played them the first time, the Rams were a little bit different and I think we were a little bit different. There are some things that have changed since then and we'll deal with it accordingly," he said. SEAHAWKS: Seattle Seahawks head coach Pete Carroll said after his club's 34-18 loss to the Atlanta Falcons on Sunday that his club is still a work in progress. Thanks to the overall dreadfulness of the NFC West, that Seahawks club could still end up hosting a first-round playoff game. Seattle's loss to Atlanta on Sunday did little to impact the division after the rest of the NFC West -- the Rams, 49ers and Cardinals -- all picked up Week 15 defeats. That has Seattle tied atop the standings with St. Louis at 6-8, with San Francisco a game back. While the Rams and 49ers will be looking to deal each other a critical loss this weekend, the Seahawks head to Tampa Bay to battle the 8-6 Buccaneers. With Seattle also set to host St. Louis on Jan. 2, the Seahawks can still return to the postseason for the first time since 2007 with a pair of victories. "As we look at it, with the way things happened again, here we go to Tampa with a tremendous amount on the line," said Carroll. "We're going to keep riding it and keep going for it as long was we can and keep fighting to end the season upright and battle for this division title no matter what the situation is." Seattle remains a playoff contender despite losses in two straight and six of eight after a solid start to the season. The club will also be looking to shake off a second half versus the Falcons in which it turned the ball over three times for 17 Atlanta points. Many wondered if quarterback Matt Hasselbeck might not get a chance to redeem himself. The veteran was stripped on a sack in his own end zone, which the Falcons recovered for a touchdown early in the third quarter, and was then intercepted on Seattle's next two possessions. That led to Carroll giving him the hook in favor of Charlie Whitehurst. Hasselbeck ended the day 10-for-17 passing for 71 yards, while Whitehurst was 8-of-16 for 83 yards. The backup also ran in a score and made good on the ensuing two-point conversion chance. Hasselbeck said afterwards he was okay with the quarterback switch. "I understand the situation. We were out of the game and it was a chance for him to go in," said Hasselbeck. "I was rooting for him. I was happy for him for running the touchdown in and getting the two-point conversion ... I'm not upset at anybody. I'm upset at how today went, but that's okay." Given Hasselbeck's experience over Whitehurst, who has started just once in six games since joining the NFL in 2006, it would have been hard to imagine Carroll making a switch for this weekend's big game. Carroll avoided a distraction on Monday by saying he is sticking with Hasselbeck versus Tampa Bay. Hasselbeck has turned the ball over 13 times in his last four games as he continues to play through a left wrist injury, including 10 interceptions and three lost fumbles. The 35-year-old has matched a career high with 17 interceptions, first set last season. CARDINALS: Two seasons ago, the Arizona Cardinals were in the Super Bowl. Now, with two games left they need a win either Christmas Day at home over Dallas or on the road in San Francisco on Jan. 2 to avoid finishing the regular season with just four wins for the first time since 2003. Following a second straight 5-11 season in 2006, the Cardinals brought in head coach Ken Whisenhunt and increased their win total to eight, nine and then 10 games in 2009. However, the offseason retirement of Kurt Warner has set Arizona back more steps than it could have ever imagined. Rookie John Skelton became the third different quarterback to start a game for the Cardinals this season when he led Arizona to a home victory over Denver last weekend. Matt Leinart came into the season as the No. 1, but was released before the start of the campaign after the Cardinals elected to go with Derek Anderson. Max Hall has also gotten the nod under center for Arizona. Skelton gave the Cards a shot in the arm with a mistake-free starting debut in a 43-13 victory over the Broncos, but he lost a fumble and was picked off once in this past Sunday's 19-12 setback at Carolina. "It seemed like every time we had a chance to do something, we made mistakes, whether it was turnovers, running into the kicker, our onside kick was short," said Whisenhunt. "You've got to give Carolina credit. They played hard. They made the plays they had to and we didn't." The loss dropped Arizona to 4-10 and officially eliminated them from the race for the NFC West crown. The Cardinals also gave the Panthers just their second victory of the season. Though Arizona has lacked consistency at the quarterback position, wide receiver Larry Fitzgerald has still found ways to perform. Already this season he became the Cardinals' all-time leader in receptions and his nine-catch, 125-yard performance versus the Panthers made the 27-year-old the second- fastest player in league history to reach 8,000 career yards, behind only Randy Moss. Moss reached the milestone at the age of 26. While the Cardinals could use all the silver-linings they can get, Fitzgerald isn't about to turn to personal statistics. "It's another milestone I've hit," said the Pro Bowl receiver. "I've never -- the worst I've been is 5-10. I just want to win two more ballgames. That's my focus at this point. It's been a rough year." Arizona's lone touchdown on Sunday came when wide receiver Steve Breaston recovered running back Tim Hightower's fumble in the end zone. The score was technically the club's 10th return touchdown this season, extending a club single-season record.

description.hltext_display: Look for Shares of Air Products & Chemicals to Potentially Pullback after Yesterday's 0.67% Rise (APD)
description.content:
Air Products & Chemicals (NYSE:APD) traded in a range yesterday that spanned from a low of $89.93 to a high of $90.90. Yesterday, the shares gained 0.67%, which took the trading range above the 3-day high of $90.00 on volume of 785,000 shares. Often times after large one-day gains, short term traders will seek to take profits and, as such, investors should be cautious.
Shares of Air Products & Chemicals are currently trading above their 50-day moving average (MA) of $85.69 and above their 200-day MA of $76.95. Look for the MA to provide support for a short-term pullback in the shares.
SmarTrend currently has shares of Air Products & Chemicals in an Uptrend and issued the Uptrend alert on July 13, 2010 at $70.56. The stock has risen 27.5% since the Uptrend alert was issued.
SmarTrend expects the share price to pullback toward the $90.00 support level. Afterwards, we expect it to move upward with its peers in the SmarTrend Chemicals- Major Diversified industry.
Keywords: air products & chemicals trading range stock news

description.hltext_display: Cancillería busca a peruana que está en riesgo de perder a sus hijos en EE.UU.
description.content:
La Dirección de Asistencia al Nacional del Ministerio de Relaciones Exteriores se encuentra en la búsqueda de cualquier dato que permita ubicar a la ciudadana peruana Barleny Elizabeth Flores Rosales con el fin de informarle que sus dos menores hijos, que se encuentran en Estados Unidos, pasarán a un proceso de adopción.
Así lo decidió de acuerdo a ley la Corte del Condado de Westchester, en Nueva York, luego de comprobar que los niños no han sido reclamados desde el 2007, pues desde ese año se encuentran bajo el cuidado del Departamento de Servicios Sociales del condado.
Se trata de M.K.B.F de nacionalidad peruana y de J.O.A de nacionalidad estadounidense .
Flores Rosales está identificada con el DNI 09966667. La Cancillería informó que quienes sepan de ella se pueden comunicar a los teléfonos 204-3265; 204-3270 y 204-3282 .

description.hltext_display: A short summary on Local pawnshop Encino
description.content:
The best way that one has in order to fulfill their emergency cash requirements, is through local pawnshop Encino. Pawning is an option where one can get loans within a very less time span, sometimes within hours and sometimes people can get loans on the spot also. Pawning has a very simple fundamental of giving loans to people. Here a person who is willing to take a loan will have to provide an asset which has a monetary value. Then the pawn broker will offer you a certain amount for the loan. This amount will be determined as per a certain percentage of the current market value of the asset that you are going to offer for pawning. You can pawn many kind of asset for the purpose of pawning. Some of the important assets that you can pawn at the local pawnshop Encino are gold, jewelry, car, guitar, watches, electronic products and many other such asset that have certain fiscal value in the market.
When you approach a local pawnshop for the purpose of taking loan, you will be given a specific time period within which you will have to repay your loan amount. This is the time in which you can either give your loan in installments or you can also it in lump sum. The choice is completely yours in this condition. But in case you are still not able to repay your loan amount within the given time period then you will have to lose your possession over the asset and the pawn broker will sell the asset of yours. They will do this and recover their money that that have offered to your. They will make it a point that they sell the asset in the price that is higher that one that was offered to you. This way they will earn profits.
Today is the world of internet and therefore many of the local pawnshops have also joined the world of web. This has made it easier for the people to get loan via pawning. People can now easily get in touch with the providers of the pawn loans and thus the paw shops have found it feasible enough to get in touch with their prospective leads. Getting in touch with the local pawnshop Encino is also very easy,. You just have to choose the best search engine out of hundreds that are preset on the web and make a quality based search.

description.hltext_display: Feature: what pay-TV wants
description.content:
Since the very first television segment’s broadcast to air in 1956, television has revolutionised from a singular, black and white channel viewed on an oversized antique wooden box to a digital, multi-network, multi-platform, 3D, flat screen phenomenon.
Bruce Gyngell’s famous line ‘Good evening, and welcome to television,’ was a monumental introduction to today’s seemingly endless possibilities of TV consumer entertainment.
Leading executives spoke at the recent SPAA Fringe Conference at Sydney’s Powerhouse Museum, addressing promising TV producers and writers with their visions for the cable channels and the innovative material which they are actively searching for.
Ross Crowley, director of Foxtel Programming and the man responsible for bringing Jerry Springer to Australian Television told producers that Foxtel has just turned 15 years old "and we are still here despite the moving of all the other broadcasters within the industry... It’s fair to say that if you were to throw a commercially interesting, fresh, original idea into the mix here in Australia, there would be a feeding frenzy."
Throughout the conference, the channel executives continuously urged producers to immerse themselves within the cable channels before approaching the networks with a pitch. "It’s not really great to pitch home decorating to the Fuel Network," Crowley said.
"You must understand the DNA of our channels, do your research and watch the subscription TV so you may understand the universe in which we operate. You need to think about why a project is good for us and understand the people and the place," said BBC Worldwide Australia general manager Tony Iffland.
Speaking about the necessity for pitches to incorporate professionals rather than just TV personalities, Lifestyle Channels general manager Nicole Sheffield states that specific industry expertise is where their ultimate success lies.
"We can teach people how to be presenters on television, but we can’t teach them to be experts. Expertise is one of the first windows which we look at."
With digital television currently booming and over 100 brands throughout the cable sector, the executives re-iterated the prominent opportunities available to potential producers who are thoughtful, thorough and innovative in their approaches.
Numerous gaps are currently available to be filled by commissioned prime-time shows. For instance The Lifestyle Channel is looking to invest in a life-changing Australian TV show in a similar genre to Secret Millionaire while the new Bio channel (targeted at women 35+ and the fastest growing subscription channel) is seeking a unique new reality show.
"Bio’s heart is in the emotional stories. Or you could just produce an emotional story about dogs and the audience will be sold," said Channel manager of Bio, Wayne Haderley.
Other current content initiatives within the channel groups include the possibility of a Lonely Planet Series and the launch of Lifestyle Home early next year, which will be opening windows for another property format.
With cable channels considering individual interests within all seasons of life, a wider viewership has been obtained.
Targeting the demographic of an older audience for example is the Crime Investigation Network (CIN). Crime, military history, and investigating the paranormal are etchings within the scope of content infused with cultural and social heritage on the network.
Programs such as Crime Investigation Australia, Toughnuts and Gangland epitomise the brand.
"Men are interested in how things work, and how they came to be, for instance war, bushrangers, and iconic Australians. Women surprisingly are more interested in crime and the reasoning behind it," CIN group channel manager, Jim Buchan, said.
With CIN’s exploration of the impulses behind crime appearing to entice a curious female audience, the genre is evidently well-balanced by the programming of military history which is of direct interest to males, rating as one of the best performing cable genres.
As television continues to intrigue, challenge, inspire, motivate and most importantly entertain a broader spectrum of audiences, the appetite for fresh, innovative ideas is swiftly escalating, with networks craving for a rippling effect of one-hit wonders. The question is – will it be you?

description.hltext_display: Reception planned for Adams’ 80th birthday
description.content:
All family and friends are invited to join Barbara Adams, Udall, and her family at a birthday reception in her honor. The event celebrating her 80th birthday will be from 2 to 4 p.m. Jan. 1 at the Udall Community Building.
Cards and birthday wishes may be sent to Barbara at 1868 E. 60th Ave. N., Udall, KS 67146.

description.hltext_display: Patrícia Amorim defende mudanças no Flamengo após 'ano ruim'
description.content:
Após conquistar o título do Campeonato Brasileiro em 2009, o Flamengo amargou uma série de problemas, principalmente fora dos gramados. Com isso, o rubro-negro passou esta temporada sem levar nenhum título. Por conta disso, a presidente Patrícia Amorim afirmou que o ano foi longe de ter sido bom, mas argumentou que em outros aspectos, o clube melhorou.
"Não foi um bom ano para o futebol, mas em relação a outras coisas foi muito diferente do que muitos dizem. Eu cuido do patrimônio físico do clube, cuidando das reformas da sede e preocupada com o Centro de Treinamento. Foi um ano que começamos a nos organizar, principalmente as finanças", comentou.
Sobre o mau desempenho do atual campeão no Campeonato Brasileiro, a mandatária defendeu a nova política do time. "Se a parte técnica do futebol não foi bem, passei a olhar mais para as categorias de base, como sempre falei que iria ser importante. Espero que no próximo ano possamos melhorar no futebol e seguir nos organizando fora dele", completou.
Para a próxima temporada, o Flamengo acertou com somente um reforço: o goleiro Felipe, ex-Corinthians, que estava no Braga-POR.

description.hltext_display: AFC North: Finally, Bengals have reason to celebrate
description.content: (Sports Network) - For one week at least, the Cincinnati Bengals looked an awful lot like the team that muscled its way to 10 victories and an AFC North title a season ago. That successful 2009 operation was built on a punishing rushing attack centered around powerful running back Cedric Benson and a physical defense that consistently stood its ground against the opposition, two elements that have been for the most part non-existent during Cincinnati's precipitous free-fall into the division cellar this year. But the Bengals got back to basics in Sunday's matchup with the Cleveland Browns, and that renewed commitment to last season's strengths resulted in the end of a painfully-long winless drought that had gone on for nearly three months. Cincinnati placed its sagging fortunes squarely on the broad shoulders of Benson against the Browns, and the sixth-year standout rewarded that approach with a dominating 31-carry, 150-yard effort that propelled the Bengals to a sorely-needed 19-17 triumph over their fellow Ohio tenants. The verdict halted a dreadful string of 10 straight losses that had matched a franchise worst for consecutive defeats in a single season. The superb showing also marked only the third time in 2010 that Benson eclipsed the century mark in a game, one season after the former first-round pick compiled a club-record seven such performances en route to a career-best total of 1,251 yards. The Bengals churned out a season-best 188 yards as a group in Sunday's win, an output more in line with the accomplishments of last year's playoff entry. Cincinnati finished the 2009 campaign ninth in the NFL with an average of 128.5 rushing yards per game, but ranked a troubling 30th in that category (87.8 ypg) heading into the Cleveland tilt. "That's how we want every game to go," said Bengals quarterback Carson Palmer, who aided his team's cause with an efficient 14-of-23, 209-yard turnover-free output under center. "We set out to be a running football team. But for a number of reasons, it hasn't been that way throughout the year. [Sunday] it was. [Sunday] it worked. A defense that's also experienced a dramatic drop-off in comparison to its 2009 standards also chipped in on Sunday, holding Cleveland factor back Peyton Hillis to a non-threatening 59 yards on 14 attempts and the Browns to a mere 278 total yards on the afternoon. "We had a great game plan coming into [Sunday]," said linebacker Rey Maualuga, who tied for the Bengals' lead with eight tackles. "We didn't allow any big plays and were the more physical team. We let a few plays get away, and we'll come in and watch film and correct that. I think overall we did a good job on both sides of the field." Cincinnati has surrendered a total of 34 points and 278 yards or less in all three of its 2010 wins. In the club's 11 losses, the defense has given up an average of 29.8 points and 363.3 total yards. With the playoffs long out of reach, the Bengals hope Sunday's positive display can serve as a springboard to a strong finish against a challenging remaining stretch. Cincinnati will host AFC West contender San Diego this coming weekend before closing out the season with a trip to North division co-leader Baltimore on Jan. 2. RAVENS: The Bengals aren't the only AFC North member that will be entering Christmas week with feelings of joy. The Baltimore Ravens lifted up their spirits, not to mention the team's chances of capturing a division title, with Sunday's rousing 30-24 victory over a surging New Orleans squad that entered M&T Bank Stadium riding a six-game winning streak. The Ravens were able to keep the high-powered Saints, who had put up 30 points or more in five straight outings coming into the pivotal Week 15 matchup, at bay by combining a stout and redemptive presentation on defense with a resurgent running game that had failed to get untracked in recent games. Baltimore bullied its way to 208 rushing yards on the day, an amount that exceeded the team's composite total over the previous three weeks, and got remarkably big production out of short-statured catalyst Ray Rice. The 5-foot-8 running back both darted and bulldozed his way to a career-high 230 yards from scrimmage, racking up a season-best 153 yards and a touchdown on 31 carries along with a team-leading 80 yards with a score on five receptions. "I saw the game plan. I knew we were going to run the ball today," said Rice afterward. Late in the year, it's a mentality thing. It just felt good to know that we were going to do something and went out and did it." While Rice and the offense were having their way with the Saints at the line of scrimmage, the Baltimore defense atoned for a shaky Week 14 showing with a stifling all-around execution. The Ravens limited New Orleans to 267 yards, the defending Super Bowl champions' lowest sum of the season, and a mere 27 on the ground. The Ravens had been lit up for 489 yards and 21 second-half points in a hard- fought overtime win at Houston just six days earlier, allowing the Texans to overcome a 28-7 third-quarter deficit to send the game into extra time. Baltimore did permit an 11-play, 75-yard drive culminating in a Drew Brees touchdown pass that tied the contest at 24-24 early in the fourth quarter, but clamped down to force a punt on New Orleans' next possession before intercepting the All-Pro quarterback on its opponents' subsequent series. "That's something that we've struggled with at times, obviously, and we've been disappointed with the consistency at the end of games," said Ravens head coach John Harbaugh on the defense's occasional lapses. "We gave up one [touchdown] at the end of the half, but they got it done at the end of the game when they had to [Sunday], and that was big." With Pittsburgh falling to the New York Jets on Sunday, Baltimore moved into a first-place tie with the Steelers in the AFC North race with just two games left to play. And while they'd lose a tiebreaker if both teams win out, the Ravens would assure themselves no worse than a Wild Card berth by prevailing in only one of their final two tests. Baltimore will visit 5-8 Cleveland this coming Sunday before hosting AFC North basement-dweller Cincinnati in Week 17. STEELERS: The Pittsburgh Steelers were able to punch their ticket into next month's AFC Playoffs, though it certainly wasn't in the fashion the division's co-front-runners would have preferred. Pittsburgh came into Sunday's marquee matchup with a desperate New York Jets outfit needing only a win or tie to earn a return to the postseason following a one-year absence. While that scenario didn't materialize due to a tough 22-17 loss, the Black and Gold still secured a spot in the six-team tournament by clinching complicated strength of victory tiebreakers over their remaining competition, namely the 8-6 grouping of Indianapolis, Jacksonville and San Diego. The achievement of one of their goals still rang a bit hollow for the Steelers after coming up just short in a tightly-played contest that wasn't decided until the final seconds. Pittsburgh outgained the previously-reeling Jets by a 378-276 margin in total yards and converted an effective 11-of-17 chances on third downs, but had their chances compromised by a pair of plays that would up playing a huge role in the ultimate outcome. The Steelers found themselves in a quick 7-0 hole when New York's Brad Smith brought back the game's opening kickoff 97 yards for a touchdown. The Jets also came up with a pivotal play on defense late in the contest, when outside linebacker Jason Taylor tripped up running back Mewelde Moore for a safety that gave the team a five-point edge with 2:38 to go and required Pittsburgh to try for a touchdown on its last drive. The Steelers nearly pulled off the feat, with quarterback Ben Roethlisberger marching the offense down from its own eight-yard line to the Jets' 10 in under two minutes, but couldn't connect on three shots at the end zone before the clock ran out. "In games like that you can go back to a number of plays, but the reality is that [the Jets] made the significant plays, particularly in the second half, third-down conversions and we didn't," Steelers head coach Mike Tomlin stated afterward. While the loss wasn't crippling for Pittsburgh, which can still obtain an AFC North title and valuable first-round bye for the conference playoffs by winning its last two games, it's margin for error has been sizably reduced. The Steelers dropped back into a tie with rival Baltimore for the division's top spot after the Ravens came up with a 30-24 decision over visiting New Orleans on Sunday. "How we respond to this will be important," said Tomlin. "We are in the thick of things here." The schedule does appear to work in the Steelers' favor, however. Next on the docket is a home game against 2-12 Carolina on Thursday night, followed by a road date at non-contending Cleveland in the finale. Pittsburgh handed the Browns a 28-10 loss at Heinz Field in mid-October, though Cleveland did finish with a 378-327 advantage in total yards that day. BROWNS: The Cleveland Browns may have found their quarterback of the future, but his return to action wasn't enough to improve the team's present situation. The sagging Browns were dealt a loss by a last-place team for a second consecutive week with this past weekend's 19-17 setback to a Cincinnati Bengals club that had dropped 10 consecutive games prior to Sunday's breakthrough. The disappointing result came on the heels of a 13-6 Week 14 defeat at AFC East cellar-dweller Buffalo in which Cleveland produced an anemic 187 total yards and nine first downs. While the offense operated slightly better this time around with rookie Colt McCoy back at the controls after sitting out three straight weeks with an ankle sprain, the Browns were ultimately done in by an inability to run the ball with any consistency and the defense's futile attempts to prevent the Bengals from doing so with authority. Cleveland gave up 188 rushing yards to Cincinnati, more than double the Bengals' season average, while getting a pedestrian 59 yards on 14 carries out of workhorse running back Peyton Hillis. That subpar exhibit on both sides drew the disdain of head coach Eric Mangini, who now finds himself back on the hot seat in the aftermath of his team's recent downturn. "In my mind, we should be able to stop the run and run the ball effectively, regardless of who we play," said Mangini after the game. "That's something that has to be a big part of playing in this division. Playing at this time of year, you have to be able to do those two things. That's my expectation, and that should be all of our expectations, because it's the nature of the division that we play in and weather that we play in." McCoy didn't show much rust from his near month-long layoff, hitting on a sharp 19-of-25 attempts for 243 yards and tossing two touchdown passes without an interception. But in spite of those good numbers, the Cleveland offense had its struggles in generating any sustained momentum over the course of the contest. The 24-year-old took responsibility for his unit's troubles, noting that the defense was placed in difficult situations on several occasions and was on the field for too long a time because of the offense's repeated stumbles. "We just have to do a better job just staying on the field," said McCoy. "We can talk about our defense and talk how they gave up a lot of yards rushing, but really a huge part of it is on us. You look at the time of possession and they were on the field almost twice as much as we were. That goes back to us. We've got to convert third downs. We've got to stay on the field longer. We've got to sustain drives." Cincinnati held the football for slightly over 38 of the game's 60 minutes, while the Browns were successful on only 2-of-8 tries on third downs. Cleveland has now averaged a meager 12 points over its last three games, which includes a 13-10 road win over Miami on Dec. 5, and may have a hard time improving upon those numbers over the final portion of the schedule. The Browns host Baltimore, which ranks fourth in the league in scoring defense (18.7 ppg), before closing out the season at home against a Pittsburgh team that's tied for first in the NFL in that category.

description.hltext_display: 首など切られ４７歳女性重傷 福岡市東区
Kuczynski ha tenido gran aceptación en inicio de la campaña, afirmaron San Román y Pérez Tello
description.content:
Los integrantes de la plancha presidencial de Pedro Pablo Kuczynski (Alianza para el Progreso) destacaron que este ha encontrado gran receptividad en los lugares que ha visitado como parte del inicio de su campaña proselitista, por haber transmitido confianza.
PPK ha sido el diálogo con los pobladores de las zonas del norte (Trujillo) y sur del país (Arequipa y Cusco) que ha recorrido.
"Hemos recibido llamadas de esperanza de todos lados. Pedro Pablo ofrece capacitación, conocimiento, tecnología, para que el pueblo pase de espectador a protagonista. Ahora tiene un reconocimiento pleno en todos los sectores", indicó San Román.
A su turno, Pérez Tello resaltó: "Kuczynski tiene ideas distintas, el Perú necesita revitalizar la política, entenderla de manera diferente, y tenerle fe. Él es un técnico dispuesto a servir".
De otro lado, San Román consideró que cuenta con una experiencia inconclusa al haber asumido en su momento la Presidencia de la República (en respuesta al autogolpe de Estado dado por Alberto Fujimori en 1992) así como la primera vicepresidencia.
"Yo ya tuve una función real, en esos cortos 18 meses de democracia logré comunicar a los ministros lo importante que era eliminar los obstáculos que impedían nuestro desarrollo. Fui escuchado, y contra viento y marea, como no podíamos aprobar las leyes al no ser mayoría en el Congreso. Eso fue un trabajo delicado de concertación", expresó.

description.hltext_display: Browns place two on IR
description.content: Berea, OH (Sports Network) - The Cleveland Browns placed linebacker Scott Fujita and cornerback Eric Wright on injured reserve Tuesday. Fujita has been out since November 14 when he strained a left knee ligament against the New York Jets. Signed as a free agent in March, he finished his ninth season in the NFL with 51 tackles, 3 1/2 sacks and an interception. Wright hurt his left knee this past Sunday in the 19-17 loss at Cincinnati. He began the season as a starter, but lost that job to rookie Joe Haden after getting beat for several touchdowns. He totaled 42 tackles and an interception along with nine passes defensed in his fourth season. To fill the roster spots, the Browns signed nose tackle Travis Ivey off the practice squad and free agent linebacker Steve Octavien. Also, the team signed fullback Tyler Clutts to the practice squad.

description.hltext_display: Obama signing 'don't ask, don't tell' repeal
description.author: MARK S. SMITH
description.content:
WASHINGTON
So many gay rights and Democratic activists were expected at the signing ceremony that the White House booked a large auditorium at the Interior Department.
"This day has come!" said an elated Mike Almy, an Air Force major discharged four years ago when his sexual orientation became known. "'Don't ask, don't tell' is over, and you no longer have to sacrifice your integrity."
While the elation is real, Pentagon officials caution it could be premature, since the bill requires service chiefs to complete implementation plans before lifting the old policy - and certify to lawmakers that it won't damage combat readiness, as critics charge.
Also, guidelines must be finalized that cover a host of practical questions, from how to educate troops to how sexual orientation should be handled in making barracks assignments.
While officials have avoided timetables, the process will probably take months.
Still, for gay and lesbian Americans, Wednesday is a watershed. And for Obama, it is a day to revel in the achievement of a goal he's long championed.
It is also the second of three expected victories in what's turned out to be - for Obama - a surprisingly productive lame-duck Congress. Weeks after his self-described "shellacking" in the midterm vote, he's won lopsided approval of a tax cut compromise, and the Senate is poised to deliver his top foreign policy goal: ratification of a new nuclear arms treaty with Russia.
Many Democratic liberals were furious over the tax package, believing Obama blithely yielded to Republican demands to retain the same tax cuts for the rich he had loudly denounced on the campaign trail. That's not the case with the repeal of don't ask, don't tell. Lifting of the ban on gays serving openly was something Obama not only campaigned on in 2008 but reiterated in this year's State of the Union speech.
"I will work with Congress and our military to finally repeal the law that denies gay Americans the right to serve the country they love because of who they are," he said in January to cheers in the House chamber, adding, "It's the right thing to do."
Born 17 years ago as a compromise between President Bill Clinton and a resistant Pentagon, the "don't ask, don't tell" policy became for gay rights campaigners a notorious roadblock on the way to full acceptance.
Speaking in June at a Gay Pride Month observance at the White House, Obama likened the fight to end it to the struggle of American blacks for civil rights.
"We have never been closer to ending this discriminatory policy," he declared.
Yet he has also faced rising discontent among gay activists who believed he hadn't moved forcefully enough. He's been heckled at campaign appearances over AIDS funding and the failure to end the military service ban.
Obama countered that as commander-in-chief, he had to ensure the ban's end is carefully prepared for.
That's just what the bill from Congress mandates.
"The implementation and certification process will not happen immediately; it will take time," Air Force Chief of Staff Gen. Norton Schwartz warned in an e-mail that went out right after Saturday's Senate vote. "Meanwhile, the current law remains in effect. All Air Force members should conduct themselves accordingly."
Military and administration officials are wrestling with numerous legal questions raised by the end of the ban - knowing that courts are waiting in the wings. They include what to do about pending expulsion proceedings, and when those ousted under don't-ask-don't-tell might apply to rejoin the armed forces.
For Almy, who appeared at a Capitol Hill ceremony Monday, the important thing is that gay and lesbian service members are no longer singled out because of who they love.

event_or_fact.property: We have never been closer to ending this discriminatory policy
